snippet: Maj. Gen. Robert Mood said Friday that “violence over the past 10 days has been intensifying willingly by both parties, with losses on both sides and significant risks to our observers.”
abstract: Maj Gen Robert Mood, the head of the United Nations observer mission in Syria, presents a gloomy assessment of its prospects, saying continued violence is preventing them from doing their job; the cease-fire is considered the first goal in a six-point peace plan designed to lead to a political dialogue between the government of Pres Bashar al-Assad and his opponents.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Dalal Mawad and Hwaida Saad from Beirut; an employee of The New York Times from Damascus, Syria; and Alan Cowell from London.

lead_paragraph: Maj. Gen. Robert Mood said Friday that “violence over the past 10 days has been intensifying willingly by both parties, with losses on both sides and significant risks to our observers.”

headline.seo: U.N. Observer Leader in Syria Says His Team Is Imperiled
headline.main: U.N. Team In Syria Is Imperiled, Leader Says
headline.print_headline: U.N. Team In Syria Is Imperiled, Leader Says
